en: A 14 -year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of a 1 -month history of intermittent right knee pain that has worsened during the past day. He rates his current pain as a 6 on a 10 -point scale and says that it worsens when he walks and lessens when he sits. During the past 2 weeks, he has been walking 1 mile daily in preparation for participation in the school marching band. He has not taken any medications for his pain. He sustained a right tibia and fibula fracture at the age of 8 years after a skateboarding accident, which was treated with internal fixation and casting. He has asthma treated with inhaled budesonide daily and inhaled albuterol a s needed. His mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus, and his maternal grandmother has osteoporosis. The patient is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in; 77th percentile) tall and weighs 88 kg (195 lb; >95th percentile); BMI is 31 kg/m2 (98th percentile). Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows hyperpigmented, thickened skin at the nape of the neck. There is tenderness to palpation of the anterior aspect of the right  hip and limited range of motion on abduct ion, internal rotation, and flexion of the right hip. The left hip and knees are nontender; range of motion is full in all directions. The remainder of the examination discloses no abnormalities. Which of the following factors in this patient’s history mos t increased his risk for developing this condition?

en: A 32 -year-old man comes to the office because of a 1 -day history of cough productive of small amounts of blood and a 2-day history of shortness of breath and swelling of his ankles. He also has a 2 -week history of progressive fatigue and episodes of dark u rine. He has no history of major medical illness and takes no medications. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 175/110 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Diffus e inspiratory crackles are heard over all lung bases. There is 2+ pitting edema of both ankles. Results of laboratory studies are shown: Hemoglobin  8.9 g/dL   Hematocrit  27%  Serum   Urea nitrogen  55 mg/dL    Creatinine  2.9 mg/dL   Urine RBC  20–40/hpf   Urinalysis also shows some dysmorphic RBCs and rare RBC casts. Examination of a kidney biopsy specimen shows  crescentic glomerulonephritis and linear deposition of IgG along the glomerular capillaries. This patient most likely has  antibodies directed again st which of the following antigens?
es: A 32-year-old man presents with a 1-day history of cough producing small amounts of blood and a 2-day history of shortness of breath and swelling of his ankles. He also has a 2-week history of progressive fatigue and episodes of dark urine. He has no history of serious illness and is on no medications. His temperature is 37°C, pulse 90/min, respirations 18/min, and blood pressure 175/110 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Diffuse and inspiratory crackles are heard at all lung bases. There is 2+ pitting edema in both ankles. Laboratory results are shown: Hemoglobin 8.9 g/dL Hematocrit 27% Serum urea nitrogen 55 mg/dL Creatinine 2.9 mg/dL Urine RBCs 20–40/hpf Urinalysis also shows a few dysmorphic RBCs and rare RBC casts. Examination of a renal biopsy specimen shows crescentic glomerulonephritis and linear deposition of IgG along the glomerular capillaries. This patient most likely has antibodies again directed against which of the following antigens?

ja: A 32-year-old man presented with a cough that produced a small amount of blood 1 day later and shortness of breath and swelling in his ankles 2 days later. His oxygen saturation was 91% on room pulse oximetry. Diffuse inspiratory crackles were heard at all lung bases. He had 2+ edema in both ankles. Laboratory findings showed hemoglobin 8.9 g/dL, hematocrit 27%, serum urea nitrogen 55 mg/dL, creatinine 2.9 mg/dL, and urinary red blood cells 20-40/hpf. Urinalysis revealed several dysmorphic red blood cells and rare red blood cell casts. Examination of a renal biopsy specimen reveals crescentic glomerulonephritis and linear deposits of IgG along the glomerular capillaries. This patient is likely to have retargeted antibodies to which of the following antigens?

Diffuse respiratory crackles are heard in all lung bases. Both ankles have 2+ punctate edema. The results of laboratory tests are shown: Hemoglobin 8.9 g/dl Hematocrit 27 % Serum urea nitrogen 55 mg/dl Creatinine 2.9 mg/dl Urine RBC 20-40/hpf Urinalysis also shows some dysmorphic RBC and rare RBC wear. Examination of the renal biopsy specimen shows crescentic glomerulonephritis and linear deposition of IgG along the glomerular capillaries. This patient most likely has antibodies against which of the following antigens again?

en: A 60 -year-old man comes to the office because of weakness, tingling of his hands and feet, irritability, and forgetfulness  for 4 months. Laboratory studies show megaloblastic anemia, serum  antiparietal cell antibodies, and increased serum concentrations of methylmalonic acid and total homocyst(e)ine. es: A 60-year-old man presents with complaints of weakness, tingling in the hands and feet, irritability, and forgetfulness for the past 4 months. Physical examination shows pallor, weakness, and spasticity. Deep tendon reflexes are increased. Vibration sensitivity is absent in the lower extremities. Laboratory studies show megaloblastic anemia, serum antibodies against parietal cells, and increased serum levels of methylmalonic acid and total homocyst(e)ine. Which of the following amino acids is most likely abnormal in this patient?
ar: A 60-year-old man comes to the clinic because of weakness and tingling in the hands and feet, irritability, and forgetfulness for 4 months. Physical examination reveals pallor, weakness, and spasticity. Deep tendon reflexes are increased. Vibration sensation is absent in the lower extremities. Laboratory studies reveal megaloblastic anemia, serum parietal cell antibodies, and increased serum methylmalonic acid and total homocysteine concentrations. Which of the following amino acids is most likely to be deficient in this patient?
cs: A 60-year-old man comes to the office because of weakness, tingling in the hands and feet, irritability, and forgetfulness of 4 months' duration. Physical examination shows pallor, weakness, and spasticity. Deep tendon reflexes are increased.  There is no sense of vibration in the lower limbs. Laboratory tests show megaloblastic anemia, serum antibodies against parietal cells, and elevated serum concentrations of methylmalonic acid and total homocyst(e)ine. Synthesis of which of the following amino acids is most likely impaired in this patient?
de: A 60-year-old man comes to the practice because he has been complaining of weakness, tingling in the hands and feet, irritability and forgetfulness for 4 months. Physical examination shows pallor, weakness and spasticity. Deep tendon reflexes are increased. Vibration sensation in the lower extremities is absent. Laboratory tests show megaloblastic anemia, antibodies against parietal cells in the serum and increased serum concentrations of methylmalonic acid and total homocysteine. The synthesis of which of the following amino acids is most likely to be impaired in this patient?

Laboratory studies reveal megaloblastic anemia, serum antiparietal cell antibodies, and elevated serum methylmalonic acid and total homocysteine concentrations. Laboratory studies reveal megaloblastic anemia, serum antiparietal cell antibodies, increased serum concentrations of methylmalonic acid, and total homocysteine (e). en: A 65 -year-old woman comes to the office for a follow -up examination 1 year after she underwent operative resection of  the right colon and chemotherapy for stage III colon cancer. She reports fatigue. Physical examination shows no  abnormalities. A staging CT scan of the chest and abdomen shows five new 2 - to 3-cm masses in the liver and both  lungs. This patient's cancer most likely spread to the lungs via which of the following structures?
es: A 65-year-old woman presents for a follow-up examination 1 year after undergoing surgical resection of the right colon and chemotherapy for stage III colon cancer. She complains of fatigue. Physical examination is unremarkable. A CT scan of the chest and abdomen shows five new 2- to 3-cm masses in the liver and both lungs. This patient's cancer is most likely to have spread to the lungs through which of the following structures?

en: A 26 -year-old man comes to the office because of a 1 -week history of increased urinary frequency accompanied by  excessive thirst. He says he has been urinating hourly. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum chemistry  studies are within the reference ranges. Urine osmolality is 50 mOsmol/kg H 2O. After administration of ADH  (vasopressin), his urine osmolality is within the reference range. The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is  dysfunction of which of the following structures?
es: A 26-year-old man presents with a 1-week history of increased urinary frequency accompanied by excessive thirst. He states that he is urinating every hour. Physical examination reveals no abnormalities. Serum biochemistry is within reference ranges. Urine osmolality is 50 mOsmol/kg H2O. Following administration of ADH (vasopressin), his urine osmolality is within reference ranges. The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is dysfunction of which of the following structures?
ar: A 26-year-old man comes to the clinic with a 1-week history of increased urinary frequency accompanied by extreme thirst. He reports that he has been urinating every hour. After administration of ADH (vasopressin), urine osmolality is within reference range. The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is dysfunction of which of the following structures?
cs: A 26-year-old man comes to the doctor's office because of increased frequency of urination accompanied by excessive thirst that has been present for a week. He states that he urinates every hour. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum chemistry is within the reference range. Urine osmolality is 50 mOsmol/kg H 2O. After administration of ADH (vasopressin), urine osmolality is within the reference range. Dysfunction of which of the following structures is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

After administration of ADH (vasopressin), urine osmolality is within reference range. The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is dysfunction of which of the following structures?

en: A 52 -year-old woman comes to the office because of a 6 -month history of intermittent headaches. Sometimes the pain  improves when the patient lies down in a quiet room. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations  are 16/min, and blood pressure is 154/100  mm Hg. The lungs are clear. Cardiac examination shows the point of maximal  impulse displaced to the left and occasional skipped beats; there are no murmurs or rubs. There is no S 3. Resting  electrocardiography shows left axis deviation w ith R waves greater than 30  mm in leads V 5 through V 6. Which of the  following processes best explains the development of the left ventricular abnormalities in this patient?
es: A 52-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of intermittent headaches. The pain is sometimes relieved when the patient lies down in a quiet room. Her temperature is 37.5°C, pulse 86/min, respirations 16/min, and blood pressure 154/100 mm Hg. The lungs are clear. Cardiac examination shows a shifted point of maximal impulse to the left and occasional skipped beats; there are no murmurs or rubs. There is no S3. The resting electrocardiogram shows left axis deviation with R waves greater than 30 mm in leads V5 through V6. Which of the following processes best explains the development of left ventricular abnormalities in this patient?
ar: A 52-year-old woman comes to the clinic with intermittent headaches for 6 months. The pain sometimes improves when the patient lies in a quiet room. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse 86/min, respirations 16/min, and blood pressure 154/100 mm Hg. The lungs are clear. Cardiac examination shows a leftward shift of the maximum pulse point and occasional skipped beats; no murmurs or rubs are present. There is no S3. Resting electrocardiogram shows left axis deviation with R waves greater than 30 mm in leads V5 to V6. Which of the following processes explains the development of left ventricular abnormalities in this patient?
cs: A 52-year-old woman comes to the doctor's office because of a six-month history of intermittent headaches. Sometimes the pain improves when the patient lies down in a quiet room. Her temperature is 37.5°C, pulse 86/min, respirations 16/min, and blood pressure 154/100 mm Hg. The lungs are clean. Examination of the heart shows the point of maximal impulse shifted to the left and occasional missed beats; no murmurs or tremors are present. S is not present 3. Resting electrocardiography shows left axis deviation with R waves greater than 30 mm in leads V 5 to V 6. Which of the following processes best explains the development of left ventricular abnormalities in this patient?
de: A 52-year-old woman comes to the office because she has been suffering from intermittent headaches for 6 months. Sometimes the pain improves when the patient lies down in a quiet room. She has a temperature of 37.5°C, a pulse of 86/min, respirations of 16/min, and a blood pressure of 154/100 mm Hg. The lungs are clear. Cardiological examination shows a left-shifted point of maximum impulse and occasional pauses; there are no murmurs or frictions. There is no S 3. The resting electrocardiogram shows left axis deviation with R waves greater than 30 mm in leads V 5 to V 6. Which of the following processes best explains the development of left ventricular abnormalities in this patient?
id: A 52-year-old woman presents to the office because of a 6-month history of intermittent headaches. The pain is sometimes relieved when the patient lies in a quiet room. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse rate is 86/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 154/100 mm Hg. Her lungs are clear. Cardiac examination shows a leftward shift in the point of maximal impulse and occasional skips; there are no murmurs or rubs. There is no S 3. Resting electrocardiography shows left axis deviation with R waves greater than 30 mm in leads V 5 through V 6. Which of the following processes best explains the development of left ventricular abnormalities in this patient?
ko: A 52-year-old woman presents to the clinic with intermittent headaches for 6 months. The pain may improve when the patient lies down in a quiet room. Her cardiac examination reveals a left-sided maximal impulse point with occasional skipped beats, no murmurs or crepitus, and no S3. A resting electrocardiogram reveals a left-axis deviation with an R wave greater than 30 mm in leads V5 through V6. Which of the following processes best explains the development of this patient's left ventricular abnormality?

Her temperature is 37.5°C, her pulse is 86 beats/min, her respirations are 16 breaths/min, and her blood pressure is 154/100 mmHg. There are no pulmonary abnormalities. Cardiac examination reveals a shift of the maximum beat point to the left, occasional skipped beats, and no murmur or friction rub. There is no murmur or friction rub. A resting electrocardiogram shows left axis deviation and R waves >30 mm in leads V5 to V6. Which process best explains the development of this patient's left ventricular abnormality?
lv: A 52-year-old woman comes to the office because she has had intermittent headaches for 6 months. Sometimes the pain improves when the patient sleeps in a quiet room. Her temperature is 37.5°C, pulse 86/min, respirations 16/min, blood pressure 154/100 mm Hg. The lungs are clean. When examining the heart, it is seen that the point of maximum impulse is shifted to the left and sometimes beats are missed; no murmurs or tremors. S 3 is absent. Electrocardiography at rest shows left axis deviation with R waves greater than 30 mm in V 5 through V 6. Which of the following processes best explains the development of left ventricular abnormalities in this patient?
nl: A 52-year-old woman presents to the office with a 6-month history of intermittent headaches. Sometimes the pain improves when the patient lies down in a quiet room. Her temperature is 37.5°C, her pulse is 86/min, her respirations are 16/min, and her blood pressure is 154/100 mm Hg. The lungs are clear. Cardiac examination shows the point of maximum impulse displaced to the left with occasional skipped beats; there are no murmurs or rubs. There is no S 3. Resting electrocardiography shows a left axial deviation with R waves greater than 30 mm in leads V 5 through V 6. Which of the following processes best explains the development of the left ventricular abnormalities in this patient?
it: A 52-year-old woman comes to the office with a 6-month history of intermittent headache. The pain sometimes improves when the patient lies down in a quiet room. The temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), the pulse is 86/min, the respirations are 16/min, and the blood pressure is 154/100 mm Hg. The lungs are clear. Cardiac examination shows a left-shifted point of maximum pulse and occasional skipped beats; there are no murmurs or friction rubs. There is no S 3. Resting electrocardiography shows a left-axis deviation with R waves greater than 30 mm in leads V 5 through V 6. Which of the following processes best explains the development of left ventricular abnormalities in this patient?

en: A 53 -year-old man comes to the physician because of a dry scaly rash on his body for the past year. He has had a 15 - kg (33-lb) weight loss during the past year. He is 178  cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and now weighs 54  kg (120 lb); BMI is  17 kg/m2. His stools have a large volume and float. Which of the following nutrient deficiencies is most likely?
es: A 53-year-old man presents to the doctor with a scaly, dry rash on his body that has been present for 1 year. He has lost 15 kg of weight during the past year. He is 178 cm tall, weighs 54 kg, and has a BMI of 17 kg/m2. His stools are bulky and float. Which of the following nutritional deficiencies is most likely?
ar: A 53-year-old man comes to the doctor because of a dry, scaly rash on his body over the past year. He has lost 15 kg (33 lb) in weight over the past year. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and now weighs 54 kg (120 lb); his BMI is 17 kg/m2. His stools are large and float on the surface of the water. Which of the following nutrient deficiencies is most likely?
cs: A 53-year-old man comes to the doctor because of a dry, scaly rash on his body that he has had for a year. He lost 15 kg in the last year. He is 178 cm tall and now weighs 54 kg; BMI is 17 kg/m2. His stools are large in volume and float. Which of the following nutrient deficiencies is most likely?
de: A 53-year-old man comes to the doctor because he has had a dry scaly rash on his body for a year. He has lost 15 kg of weight in the last year. He is 178 cm tall and now weighs 54 kg; BMI is 17 kg/m2. His stool is large in volume and floats. Which of the following nutritional deficiencies is most likely?
id: A 53-year-old man comes to his physician because of a dry, scaly rash on his body that has persisted for the past year. He has lost 15 kg (33 lb) over the past year. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and now weighs 54 kg (120 lb); his BMI is 17 kg/m2. His stools are large in volume and float. Which of the following nutritional deficiencies is most likely to be present?
ko: A 53-year-old man presents to his doctor with a dry, scaly rash on his body for the past year. He has lost 15 kg (33 lb) in weight over the past year. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and currently weighs 54 kg (120 lb) with a BMI of 17 kg/m2. He has a large, floating stool. Which of the following is most likely a nutrient deficiency?
ja: A 53-year-old man is seen with a 1-year history of a dry, scaly rash on his body. He has lost 15 kg in the past year. His height is 178 cm, weight is 54 kg, and BMI is 17 kg/m2. His stools are bulky and floating. Which nutritional deficiency is most likely?
lv: A 53-year-old man comes to the doctor because of a dry, scaly rash on his body for the past year. He has lost 15 kg (33 lbs) in the last year. His height is 178 cm, weight - 54 kg, body mass index is 17 kg/m2. His stools are bulky and floaty. Which of the following nutrient deficiencies is most likely?

He is 178 cm tall and currently weighs 54 kg; BMI is 17 kg/m2. His stools are bulky and float. Which of the following nutrient deficiencies is most likely?
it: A 53-year-old man comes to the doctor because of a dry, scaly rash on his body for a year. He has lost 15 kg (33 lb) of weight in the past year. en: Serum LDL -cholesterol concentrations are measured in blood samples collected from 25 healthy volunteers. The data  follow a normal distribution. With a 95% confidence level, the true mean for the population from which this  sample was drawn falls within which of the following ranges (in mg/dL)?

At the 95% confidence level, the true mean for the population from which this sample was drawn falls in which of the following ranges (in mg/dL)?

en: A 39 -year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6 -month history of progressive shortness of breath. He has had  a cough productive of white sputum for 2  years. He smoked 1  pack of cigarettes daily for 16  years but quit 10  years ago.  He is in mild resp iratory distress with pursed lips and a barrel chest; he is using the accessory muscles of respiration.  Breath sounds are distant and crackles are present in the lower lung fields bilaterally. Pulmonary function tests show a  decreased FEV 1:FVC ratio, incre ased residual volume, and decreased diffusion capacity. An x -ray of the chest shows  hyperinflation and hypertranslucency of the lower lobes of both lungs. Which of the following is the most likely  diagnosis?
es: A 39-year-old man presents to the physician with a 6-month history of progressive shortness of breath. He has had a cough with white sputum for 2 years. He smoked 1 pack of cigarettes a day for 16 years but quit 10 years ago. He has mild shortness of breath with pursed lips and a barrel chest; he uses accessory muscles of respiration. Breath sounds are distant, and there are crackles in the lower lung fields bilaterally. Pulmonary function tests show a decreased FEV1:FVC ratio, increased residual volume, and decreased diffusing capacity. A chest x-ray shows hyperinflation and hyperlucency of the lower lobes of both lungs. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
ar: A 39-year-old man comes to the physician with a 6-month history of progressive dyspnea. He has had a cough producing white sputum for 2 years. He smoked a pack of cigarettes a day for 16 years but quit 10 years ago. He has mild dyspnea with pursed lips and a pursed chest; he uses the accessory muscles of breathing. Breath sounds are distant and there are crackles in the lower lung fields bilaterally. Pulmonary function tests show a decreased FEV 1:FVC ratio, increased residual volume, and decreased diffusing capacity. Chest x-rays show hyperinflation and hyperlucentity of the lower lobes of both lungs. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
cs: A 39-year-old man presents to the physician with a 6-month history of progressive dyspnea. He has had a cough with white sputum for 2 years. He smoked 1 pack of cigarettes a day for 16 years, but stopped 10 years ago.  He has mild respiratory distress with pursed lips and a barrel chest; uses accessory respiratory muscles.  Breath sounds are distant and crackles are present in the lower lung fields bilaterally. Pulmonary function tests show a decreased FEV 1:FVC ratio, increased residual volume, and decreased diffusing capacity. A chest X-ray shows hyperinflation and hypertranspiration of the lower lobes of both lungs. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
de: A 39-year-old man comes to the physician because he has been experiencing increasing shortness of breath for 6 months. He has had a cough with white sputum for 2 years. He smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 16 years but quit 10 years ago. He is in mild dyspnea with pursed lips and a barrel-shaped chest; he is using the accessory respiratory muscles. en: A 24 -year-old woman is brought to the physician 1  month after she was involved in a motor vehicle collision that left  her weak and unable to walk. Physical examination shows weakness of both hands and atrophy of the intrinsic hand  muscles bilaterally. Ther e is weakness and increased muscle tone of the lower extremities on passive range of motion.  Deep tendon reflexes are normal at the biceps and triceps bilaterally and are increased at the knees and ankles. Babinski  sign is present bilaterally. Sensation to  pinprick is absent at and below the level of the clavicles. The lesion in this patient  is most likely located at which of the following spinal cord levels?

en: A 25 -year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3 -day history of fever, chills, severe headache, weakness, muscle  pain, loss of appetite, vomiting, diarrhea, and moderate abdominal pain. en: A 5-month -old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother because of a 10 -day history of “coughing spells” that occur  several times daily and last 1 to 2 minutes; he often vomits afterwards. en: A 46 -year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1 -month history of fatigue, weakness, and palpitations. She  has advanced kidney disease as a result of continued use of combination analgesics for low back pain. She has  hypertension well controlled with a loop diuretic, a β -adrenergic blocker, and a dihydropyridine calcium channel  blocker. She ha s a history of gastritis and hemorrhoids associated with occult blood in the stools. She is in no acute  distress. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 74/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is  150/86  mm Hg. Physical examination shows m ild midepigastric tenderness to palpation and 2+  edema of the lower  extremities. Cardiac examination shows an S 4 gallop. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. en: A 30 -year-old woman comes to the office  because of a 4 -day history of an increasingly severe, painful rash over her  body and in her mouth. The rash began over her trunk area but  spread within a day to her face and extremities. Two  days  before development o f the rash, she had  flu-like symptoms with muscle aches and fatigue as well as a nonproductive  cough, sore throat, and runny nose. Ten days ago, she began treatment with trimethoprim -sulfamethoxazole for a urinary  tract infection; she takes no other medica tions. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are  25/min, and blood pressure is 165/105 mm Hg. Physical examination shows diffuse brownish red macular exanthema  with bullous lesions. Epidermis at an uninvolved site can be removed w ith mild tangential pressure. Examination of a      biopsy specimen of one of the lesions shows necrosis of keratinocytes throughout the epidermis. There is minimal  lymphocytic infiltration within the superficial dermis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Examination of a biopsy specimen of one lesion shows necrosis of keratinocytes throughout the epidermis. There is minimal infiltration of lymphocytes in the superficial dermis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
nl: A 30-year-old woman presents with a 4-day history of a progressively worsening, painful rash over her body and in her mouth. The rash began on her trunk but spread to her face and extremities within 1 day. Two days before the rash developed, she had flu-like symptoms with muscle aches and fatigue, as well as a nonproductive cough, sore throat, and runny nose. Ten days ago, she began treatment with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection; she is taking no other medications. Her temperature is 39.0°C, her pulse is 120/min, her respirations are 25/min, and her blood pressure is 165/105 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals diffuse brown-red macular exanthema with bullous lesions. Epidermis in an unaffected area can be eviscerated with mild tangential pressure. Examination of a biopsy specimen from one of the lesions shows necrosis of keratinocytes throughout the epidermis. There is minimal lymphocytic infiltration into the superficial dermis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
it: A 30-year-old woman presents to the office because of a 4-day history of an increasingly severe and painful rash on her body and mouth. Ten days ago, she began treatment with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection; she is not taking any other medications. Her temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 165/105 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a diffuse reddish-brown macular rash with bullous lesions. The epidermis at an uninvolved site can be removed with gentle tangential pressure. Examination of a biopsy specimen from one of the lesions shows keratinocyte necrosis throughout the epidermis. Minimal lymphocytic infiltration is present in the superficial dermis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

en: A 3800 -g (8-lb 6-oz) newborn is delivered vaginally at 39 weeks' gestation after an uncomplicated pregnancy. Apgar  scores are 9 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. en: An 80 -year-old woman is brought to the emergency department (ED) 30  minutes after she fell out of her wheelchair at  home. This is the second visit to the ED for a fall during the past 3  months. She lives with her daughter and son -in-law,  who say they “do t he best we can.” The patient has dementia, Alzheimer type, coronary artery disease, type  2 diabetes  mellitus, and hypertension. Current medications are amlodipine, aspirin, atorvastatin, donepezil, long -acting insulin, and  lisinopril. Five years ago, she u nderwent bilateral below -the-knee amputations because of infected ulcers of the feet.  She uses a wheelchair for ambulation. Ten years ago, she underwent three -vessel coronary artery bypass grafting. She  has smoked one -half pack of cigarettes daily for 60  years. She drinks one shot of whiskey nightly. She is thin and appears  ill and disheveled. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is  120/80  mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 2  L/min of oxygen by nasal cannula  shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. Physical  examination shows temporal wasting. There are scattered ecchymoses over the abdomen and all extremities. No other  abnormalities are noted. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial history to obtain  from this patient?
es: An 80-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department (ED) 30 minutes after falling out of her wheelchair at home. The patient has Alzheimer's dementia, coronary artery disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. She is currently taking amlodipine, aspirin, atorvastatin, donepezil, long-acting insulin, and lisinopril. She underwent bilateral below-knee amputations five years ago due to infected foot ulcers. She is wheelchair-bound. She underwent a three-vessel coronary bypass surgery ten years ago. She has smoked a half-pack of cigarettes a day for 60 years. She drinks a shot of whiskey every night. She is thin and appears ill and disheveled. Her temperature is 37.2°C, pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry with 2 L/min of oxygen via nasal cannula shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. Physical examination shows temporal atrophy. There are scattered ecchymoses over the abdomen and all extremities. No other abnormalities are noted. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial history to obtain for this patient?

id: An 80-year-old woman was brought to the Emergency Department (ED) 30 minutes after she fell out of her wheelchair at home. This was her second visit to the ED for a fall in the past 3 months. She lives with her daughter and son-in-law, who stated that they are “doing the best we can.” The patient has dementia, Alzheimer’s disease, coronary artery disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. Her current medications include amlodipine, aspirin, atorvastatin, donepezil, long-acting insulin, and lisinopril. Five years ago, she had bilateral below-the-knee amputations for infected leg ulcers. She uses a wheelchair for ambulation. Ten years ago, she had a three-vessel coronary artery bypass graft. She has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 60 years. She drinks one glass of whiskey each night. She is thin and appears ill and disheveled. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse rate is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry with oxygen at 2 L/min via nasal cannula shows oxygen saturation of 95%. Physical examination shows temporal wasting. There are scattered ecchymoses over the abdomen and all extremities. No other abnormalities are noted. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial history to obtain from this patient?
ko: An 80-year-old woman was brought to the emergency room (ED) 30 minutes after falling from her wheelchair at home. This was her second visit to the ED for a fall in the past 3 months. She lives with her daughter and son-in-law, who say she is "doing her best." She has dementia, Alzheimer's disease, coronary artery disease, type 2 diabetes, and high blood pressure. Her current medications include amlodipine, aspirin, atorvastatin, donepezil, long-acting insulin, and lisinopril. Five years ago, she had a bilateral below-the-knee amputation due to infected foot ulcers. She uses a wheelchair to walk. Ten years ago, she had three coronary artery bypass grafts. She has smoked a pack and a half of cigarettes a day for 60 years. She drinks a glass of whiskey every night. She appears thin, sick, and disheveled. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse 80/min, respirations 20/min, and blood pressure 120/80 mmHg. Pulse oximetry using 2 L/min of oxygen via nasal cannula reveals an oxygen saturation of 95%. Physical examination reveals wasting of time. There are scattered ecchymoses throughout the abdomen and extremities. There are no other abnormal findings. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial history to obtain from this patient?
ja: An 80-year-old woman fell from her wheelchair at home and presented to the emergency department 30 minutes later. This was her second visit to the emergency department after a fall in the past 3 months. She lives with her daughter and son-in-law, and says they are "doing everything they can." The patient has Alzheimer's disease, coronary artery disease, type 2 diabetes, and hypertension. Her current medications are amlodipine, aspirin, atorvastatin, donepezil, long-acting insulin, and lisinopril. Five years ago, she underwent bilateral below-knee amputation for infected ulcers in her feet. She uses a wheelchair to walk. She underwent three-vessel coronary artery bypass 10 years ago. She has smoked one and a half packs of cigarettes daily for 60 years. She drinks one shot of whiskey every night. She is thin, sickly, and appears sloppy. Her temperature is 37.2°C, pulse is 80 beats/min, respirations are 20 breaths/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. Pulse oximetry is performed with oxygen inhaled via nasal cannula at 2 L/min and oxygen saturation is 95%. Physical examination reveals temporal weakness. Scattered erythema over the abdomen and extremities. No other abnormalities are found. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial history to take with this patient?
lv: An 80-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department (ED) 30 minutes after falling from her wheelchair at home. This is the second ED visit for a fall in the last 3 months. She lives with her daughter and son-in-law, who say they are "doing the best they can." The patient has dementia of the Alzheimer type, coronary artery disease, type 2 diabetes and hypertension. Currently taking amlodipine, aspirin, atorvastatin, donepezil, long-acting insulin and lisinopril. Five years ago, she underwent a bilateral below-the-knee amputation due to infected foot ulcers.  She uses a wheelchair to move around. Ten years ago, she underwent three-vessel coronary artery bypass grafting. She has smoked half a pack of cigarettes a day for 60 years. She drinks one shot of whiskey every night. She is thin and looks sick and cold. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse 80/min, respirations 20/min, and blood pressure 120/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry using 2 L/min of oxygen via a nasal cannula shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. Physical examination shows temporal weakening. There are scattered ecchymoses on the abdomen and all limbs. No other abnormalities were observed. Which of the following is most appropriate for obtaining the initial history from this patient?

There are scattered ecchymoses over the abdomen and all extremities. There are no other abnormalities. Which of the following questions is most appropriate to ask this patient?
it: An 80-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department (ED) 30 minutes after falling from her wheelchair at home. This is her second ED visit for a fall in the past 3 months. Her current medications include amlodipine, aspirin, atorvastatin, donepezil, long-acting insulin, and lisinopril. The temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), the pulse is 80/min, the respirations are 20/min, and the blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry with 2 L/min of oxygen via nasal cannula shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. The physical examination shows temporal wasting. Scattered ecchymoses are present on the abdomen and all extremities. No other abnormalities are noted. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial history to obtain for this patient?

en: A 25 -year-old woman comes to the physician because of a long history of pain with menses. The pain occurs on the first  day of her 5 -day menstrual period and lasts all day. She rates the pain as 10 on a 10 -point scale. The most appropriate  initial pharmacot herapy to relieve this patient's pain has which of the following mechanisms of action?
es: A 25-year-old woman presents to the physician with a long history of menstrual pain. The pain begins on the first day of her 5-day menstrual period and lasts throughout the day. She rates the pain as 10 on a 10-point scale. Which of the following mechanisms of action is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy to relieve this patient's pain?
ar: A 25-year-old woman comes to her physician because of a long history of menstrual pain. The pain occurs on the first day of her 5-day menstrual cycle and persists throughout the day. She rates the pain as 10 on a 10-point scale. The most appropriate initial drug therapy for this patient's pain has which of the following mechanisms of action?
cs: A 25-year-old woman comes to the doctor because of long-term menstrual pain. The pains appear on the first day of the five-day period and last the whole day. She rates the pain as a 10 on a ten-point scale. Which of the following mechanisms of action is the most appropriate initial drug to relieve this patient's pain?
de: A 25-year-old woman comes to the doctor because she has been suffering from pain during her menstrual cycle for a long time. The pain begins on the first day of her 5-day menstrual cycle and lasts all day. She rates the pain as 10 on a 10-point scale. Which of the following mechanisms of action is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy to relieve this patient's pain?
id: A 25-year-old woman comes to her physician because of a long history of painful menstrual periods. The pain occurs on the first day of a 5-day menstrual period and lasts throughout the day. She rates her pain as 10 on a 10-point scale. The most appropriate initial pharmacotherapeutic therapy to relieve this patient's pain has which of the following mechanisms of action?
ko: A 25-year-old woman comes to the hospital because of chronic menstrual pain. The pain starts on the first day of her 5-day menstrual period and lasts all day. She rates her pain as a 10 on a 10-point scale. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial drug therapy to relieve this patient's pain?
ja: A 2-year-old woman visits the hospital because of a long history of menstrual cramps. The pain occurs on the first day of each 5-day period and continues throughout the day. She rates her menstrual cramps as a 10 on a 10-point scale. Which of the following mechanisms of action would be the most appropriate initial pharmacologic therapy to relieve this patient's pain?
lv: A 25-year-old woman comes to the doctor because she has had pain during her periods for a long time. The pain starts on the first day of her 5-day period and lasts all day. She rates the pain as 10 on a 10-point scale. Which of the following mechanisms of action is most appropriate for this patient's pain relief?
nl: A 25-year-old woman presents to her physician with a long history of menstrual pain. The pain occurs on the first day of her 5-day menstrual period and lasts all day. She rates the pain as a 10 on a 10-point scale. Which of the following mechanisms of action is most likely to relieve this patient's pain?
it: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a long history of menstrual pain. The pain occurs on the first day of a 5-day menstrual period and lasts all day. The pain is rated as 10 on a 10-point scale. The most appropriate initial drug therapy to relieve this patient's pain has which of the following mechanisms of action?

en: A randomized clinical trial is conducted to compare wound healing and cosmetic differences between two surgical  procedures for closing skin wounds following cesarean delivery. A total of 1000 women undergoing cesarean delivery  during a 6 -month period are enrolled in the study, which was 85% of the total number of patients undergoing the  procedure. The results show a wound infection rate of 12 cases per 1000 women for Procedure A and 18 cases per 1000  women for Procedure B. Which of the following is the best estimate of the absolute risk reduction for wound infection  following Procedur e A compared with Procedure B?
es: A randomized clinical trial is conducted to compare wound healing and cosmetic differences between two surgical procedures to close skin wounds after cesarean delivery. A total of 1000 women undergoing cesarean delivery over a 6-month period are enrolled in the study, which was 85% of the total number of patients undergoing the procedure. The results show a wound infection rate of 12 cases per 1000 women for procedure A and 18 cases per 1000 women for procedure B. Which of the following is the best estimate of the absolute reduction in risk of wound infection after procedure A compared with procedure B?
ar: A randomized clinical trial was conducted to compare wound healing and cosmetic differences between two surgical procedures for skin wound closure after cesarean delivery. A total of 1,000 women who had a cesarean delivery over a 6-month period were enrolled in the study, representing 85% of the total number of patients who underwent the procedure. The results show a wound infection rate of 12 cases per 1,000 women for procedure A and 18 cases per 1,000 women for procedure B. Which of the following is the best estimate of the absolute reduction in the risk of wound infection after procedure A compared with procedure B?
cs: A randomized clinical trial is being conducted to compare wound healing and cosmetic differences between two surgical procedures for skin wound closure following cesarean delivery. A total of 1,000 women undergoing caesarean section within 6 months are included in the study, which was 85% of the total number of patients undergoing this procedure. The results show a wound infection rate of 12 cases per 1000 women for procedure A and 18 cases per 1000 women for procedure B. Which of the following best estimates the absolute reduction in wound infection risk after procedure A compared with procedure B?
de: A randomized clinical trial compares wound healing and cosmetic differences between two surgical procedures for closing skin wounds after cesarean delivery. A total of 1000 women who underwent cesarean delivery within 6 months were enrolled in the study, representing 85% of the total number of patients who underwent the procedure. The results show a wound infection rate of 12 cases per 1000 women for procedure A and 18 cases per 1000 women for procedure B. id: A randomized clinical trial was conducted to compare wound healing and cosmetic differences between two surgical procedures for skin wound closure after cesarean delivery. ko: A randomized clinical trial is conducted to compare the wound healing and cosmetic differences between two surgical techniques for skin wound closure after cesarean section. The results showed a wound infection rate of 12 per 1,000 women for procedure A and 18 per 1,000 women for procedure B. Which of the following best estimates the absolute risk reduction in wound infection with procedure B compared with procedure A?

The results showed that procedure A had a wound infection rate of 12 cases per 1,000 women, and procedure B had a wound infection rate of 18 cases per 1,000 women.

The study includes 1,000 women who underwent caesarean sections within 6 months, which was 85% of the total number of patients who underwent the procedure. Which of the following is the best estimate of the absolute reduction in risk of wound infection after procedure A compared to procedure B?

The results show a wound infection rate of 12 cases per 1000 women for procedure A and 18 cases per 1000 women for procedure B. it: A randomized clinical trial was conducted to compare wound healing and cosmetic differences between two surgical procedures for skin wound closure after cesarean section. One thousand women who underwent cesarean section during a 6-month period were enrolled in the study, representing 85% of the total number of patients who underwent the procedure. The results showed a wound infection rate of 12 cases per 1000 women for procedure A and 18 cases per 1000 women for procedure B. en: A 58-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease comes to the clinic with his wife for a follow -up  examination. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35  years. He has tried to quit smoking twice but was  unsuccessful both times. At today’ s visit, when the physician asks the patient about smoking cessation, he says he is not  ready to do so. The patient’s wife states her husband’s smoking makes her cough and gives her chest tightness. Which  of the following is the most appropriate physician statement?
es: A 58-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease comes to the office with his wife for a follow-up exam. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes a day for 35 years. He has tried to quit twice but has not been successful. At today's visit, when the doctor asks the patient about quitting smoking, he says he is not ready to quit. The patient's wife states that her husband's smoking makes him cough and causes chest tightness. Which of the following is the most appropriate statement by the doctor?
ar: A 58-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) comes to the clinic with his wife for a follow-up examination. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes a day for 35 years. He has tried to quit smoking twice but was unsuccessful both times. At today's visit, when the doctor asked the patient about quitting smoking, he said he was not ready to do so. The patient's wife reports that her husband's smoking causes her to cough and have chest tightness. Which of the following is the most appropriate statement by the doctor?
cs: A 58-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease comes to the clinic with his wife for a follow-up examination. He smoked one pack of cigarettes a day for 35 years. He tried to quit smoking twice, but failed both times. When the doctor asks the patient at today's visit about the possibility of quitting smoking, he says that he is not ready to do so. The patient's wife reports that her husband's smoking makes her cough and causes tightness in her chest. Which of the following statements by the physician is most appropriate?
de: A 58-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease comes to the clinic with his wife for a follow-up visit. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes a day for 35 years. He has tried to quit smoking twice, but both times he was unsuccessful. When the doctor asks the patient about quitting smoking at today's visit, he says he is not ready. The patient's wife states that her husband's smoking causes her to cough and feel tight in her chest. Which of the following statements by the doctor is most appropriate?
id: A 58-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease comes to the clinic with his wife for a follow-up examination. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. He has tried to quit smoking twice but has been unsuccessful. At today's visit, when the doctor asked the patient about quitting smoking, he said that he was not ready to do so. The patient's wife said that her husband's smoking habit caused her to cough and feel chest tightness. Which statement from the doctor is most accurate?
ko: A 58-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease comes to the hospital with his wife for follow-up. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes a day for 35 years. He has tried to quit smoking twice but has failed both times. At today's visit, the doctor asks the patient about quitting, and the patient says he is not ready to quit. The patient's wife says that her husband's smoking causes her to cough and have chest tightness. Which of the following statements is most appropriate for the doctor?
ja: A 58-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease comes to the clinic with his wife for a follow-up visit. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for 35 years. He has tried to quit smoking twice, but has failed. During today's appointment, the physician asks the patient about quitting smoking, and he responds that he is not ready to quit. The patient's wife states that her husband's smoking makes her cough and gives her chest tightness. Which of the following statements by the physician is most appropriate?
lv: A 58-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease comes to the clinic with his wife for a preventive examination. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes a day for 35 years. He has tried to quit smoking twice, but failed both times. When the doctor asks the patient about quitting smoking during today's visit, he says he is not ready to do so. The patient's wife claims that her husband's smoking causes her to cough and have chest tightness. Which of the following statements is the most appropriate statement by the physician?
nl: A 58-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease comes to the clinic with his wife for a follow-up examination. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes a day for 35 years. He has tried to quit smoking twice, but both times without success. When the physician asks the patient to quit smoking during today's visit, he says that he is not ready to do so. The patient's wife says that her husband's smoking makes her cough and gives her chest tightness. Which of the following statements by the physician is most appropriate?
it: A 58-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease comes to the clinic with his wife for a follow-up visit. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes a day for 35 years. He has tried to quit smoking twice, but has been unsuccessful both times. At today's visit, when the doctor asks the patient to quit smoking, he states that he is not ready to quit. The patient's wife states that her husband's smoking causes her to cough and feel tight in her chest. Which of the following statements is most appropriate for the doctor to make?

en: Seven days after admission to the psychiatric unit for treatment of eating disorders, a hospitalized 20 -year-old woman  has a 2 -day history of moderate mouth pain on the inside of both cheeks. She also reports feeling "worthless and fat."  Fluoxetine was sta rted on admission. She appears distressed. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 77 kg (170 lb);  BMI is 27 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows bilateral swelling of the parotid and  submandibular glands, discoloration  of several teeth, and scarring on the dorsum of the right hand. Mental status  examination shows no suicidal ideation or intent. Results of laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. A  medication with which of the following mechanisms of action is  most appropriate to treat this patient's current  symptoms?
es: Seven days after admission to the psychiatric unit for the treatment of eating disorders, a 20-year-old inpatient woman presents with a 2-day history of moderate pain in her mouth, on the inside of both cheeks. She also reports feeling "worthless and fat." She was placed on fluoxetine on admission. She appears distressed. She is 170 cm tall and weighs 77 kg; her BMI is 27 kg/m2. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows bilateral parotid and submandibular gland swelling, discoloration of several teeth, and scarring on the dorsum of her right hand. Mental status examination shows no suicidal ideation or attempt. Laboratory results are within reference ranges. Which of the following mechanisms of action is most appropriate to treat this patient's current symptoms?
ar: Seven days after being admitted to the psychiatric unit for treatment of an eating disorder, a 20-year-old woman is hospitalized with moderate oral pain on the inside of her cheeks. She also reports feeling “worthless and fat.” Fluoxetine is given on admission. She appears distressed. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall, weighs 77 kg (170 lb); body mass index (BMI) is 27 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals bilateral swelling of the parotid and submandibular glands, discoloration of several teeth, and scarring of the dorsum of the right hand. Mental status examination reveals no suicidal ideation or intent. Laboratory findings are within reference ranges. Which of the following mechanisms of action is most appropriate for treating this patient’s current symptoms?
cs: Seven days after being admitted to a psychiatric ward for treatment of an eating disorder, a 20-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital with mild mouth pain on the inner side of both cheeks for two days. She also states that she feels "worthless and fat".  Fluoxetine was administered on admission. She seems upset. She is 170 cm tall and weighs 77 kg; BMI is 27 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows bilateral swelling of the parotid and submandibular glands, discoloration of several teeth, and scarring on the dorsum of the right hand. A mental status examination shows no suicidal ideation or intent. The results of laboratory examinations are within the reference range. Which of the following mechanisms of action is most appropriate for treating this patient's current symptoms?
de: Seven days after admission to the psychiatric unit for treatment of eating disorders, a 20-year-old woman has been complaining of moderate mouth pain on the inside of both cheeks for two days. She also reports feeling "worthless and fat." Fluoxetine was administered upon admission. She appears distraught. Her height is 170 cm and her weight is 77 kg; BMI is 27 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals bilateral parotid and submandibular gland swelling, discoloration of several teeth, and a scar on the back of the right hand. Mental status examination reveals no suicidal thoughts or intent. Laboratory results are within reference ranges. Which medication with which of the following mechanisms of action is most appropriate for treating this patient's current symptoms?
id: Seven days after admission to a psychiatric unit for treatment of an eating disorder, a 20-year-old woman was hospitalized with a 2-day history of moderate oral pain on the inside of both cheeks. She also reported feeling “worthless and fat.” Fluoxetine was discontinued at the time of admission. She appeared depressed. She was 5 ft 7 in (170 cm) tall and weighed 170 lb (77 kg); BMI 27 kg/m2. Vital signs were within normal limits. Physical examination revealed bilateral swelling of the parotid and submandibular glands, discoloration of several teeth, and scarring on the dorsum of the right hand. Mental status examination revealed no suicidal ideation or intent. Laboratory findings were within reference ranges. Which medication with the most appropriate mechanism of action would be most appropriate to treat the patient’s current symptoms?
ko: A 20-year-old woman admitted to a psychiatric unit for treatment of an eating disorder for 7 days presents with moderate oral pain on the inside of both cheeks for 2 days. She also reports feeling "useless and fat." She was prescribed fluoxetine at the time of admission. She appears distressed. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall, weighs 77 kg (170 lb), and has a BMI of 27 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals bilateral parotid and submandibular gland edema, multiple discolored teeth, and a scar on the back of her right hand. Mental status examination reveals no suicidal ideation or intent. Laboratory results are within reference limits. Which of the following medications would most likely be effective in treating this patient's current symptoms?
ja: On day 7 of admission to a psychiatric unit for treatment of an eating disorder, a 20-year-old hospitalized woman has had moderate mouth sores on the insides of both cheeks for the past 2 days. She also reports feeling "worthless and fat." Fluoxetine was prescribed on admission. She appears distressed. Height is 170 cm, weight 77 kg, and BMI 27 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals bilateral swelling of the parotid and submandibular glands, discoloration of several teeth, and scarring on the dorsum of the right hand. Mental status examination reveals no suicidal ideation or intent. Laboratory test results are within reference limits. Which drug has the most appropriate mechanism of action to treat this patient's current symptoms?
lv: Seven days after hospitalization in a psychiatric unit for treatment of an eating disorder, a 20-year-old woman hospitalized 2 days after conception presents with moderate oral pain on the inside of both cheeks. She also reports feeling "worthless and fat."  Fluoxetine was used during admission. She looks depressed. She is 170 cm tall and weighs 77 kg; BMI is 27 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows bilateral swelling of the parotid and mandibular glands, discoloration of several teeth, and scarring on the dorsum of the right hand. A mental status examination shows no suicidal ideation or intent. The results of laboratory tests are within reference limits. Which of the following mechanisms of action is the most appropriate medication to treat this patient's current symptoms?
nl: Seven days after admission to a psychiatric unit for treatment of an eating disorder, a 20-year-old woman admitted to the hospital experienced moderate pain in the mouth on the inside of both cheeks for 2 days. She also reported feeling "worthless and fat." Fluoxetine was administered on admission. She appeared distressed. She is 170 cm tall and weighs 77 kg; BMI is 27 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals bilateral parotid and submandibular gland swelling, discoloration of several teeth, and scarring on the dorsum of the right hand. Mental status examination reveals no suicidal ideation or intent. Laboratory results are within reference ranges. A medication with which of the following mechanisms of action would be most appropriate to treat this patient's current symptoms?
it: Seven days after admission to the psychiatric unit for treatment of eating disorders, a 20-year-old female admitted has a 2-day history of moderate mouth pain on the inside of both cheeks. She also reports feeling "worthless and fat." Fluoxetine was started on admission. She appears distressed. She is 170 cm tall and weighs 77 kg; her BMI is 27 kg/m2. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows bilateral swelling of the parotid and submandibular glands, discoloration of some teeth, and scarring on the dorsum of the right hand. Mental status examination shows no suicidal ideation or thoughts. Laboratory results are within reference ranges. Which of the following mechanisms of action is most appropriate to treat this patient's current symptoms?

en: A 35 -year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 15 weeks’ gestation is brought to the hospital in active labor. The physician  care team confers and determines that the birth cannot be prevented and that the fetus will not survive. After explaining  this fact to the patient, the patient says, "I know it is a long shot, but I still want my baby resuscitated and everything  done to save him." After empathizing with the patient, which of the following is the most appropriate initial response by  the physician?
es: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, 15 weeks gestation, is brought to the hospital in active labor. The medical team consults and determines that delivery cannot be prevented and the fetus will not survive. After explaining this fact to the patient, the patient says, "I know it's a long shot, but I still want you to resuscitate my baby and do everything you can to save him." After empathizing with the patient, which of the following is the most appropriate initial response by the physician?
ar: A 35-year-old woman, 15 weeks pregnant, is brought to the hospital in active labor. The healthcare team consults and decides that the birth cannot be prevented and that the fetus will not survive. After explaining this fact to the patient, the patient says, "I know it's out of the question, but I still want to resuscitate my baby and do everything I can to save her." After empathizing with the patient, which of the following is the most appropriate initial response from the physician after empathizing with the patient?
cs: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, 15 weeks pregnant, who is actively in labor, is brought to the hospital. The medical care team consults and decides that the birth cannot be prevented and that the fetus will not survive. After explaining this fact, the patient says, "I know it's risky, but I still want my baby resuscitated and everything done to save him." After empathizing with the patient, which of the following is the most appropriate initial response for the physician?
de: A 35-year-old woman, Gravida 2, Para 1, at 15 weeks gestation, is brought to the hospital with active labor. The medical team consults and determines that the birth cannot be prevented and that the fetus will not survive. After explaining this fact to the patient, she says: "I know it is very unlikely, but I still want my baby to be resuscitated and everything done to save him." What is the most appropriate first reaction from the doctor after empathizing with the patient?
id: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 2, stage 1, at 15 weeks gestation is brought to the hospital in active labor. The medical team treating the patient has determined that labor cannot be prevented and the fetus will not survive. After explaining this fact to the patient, the patient states, "I know this is a tough shot, but I still want my baby resuscitated and everything done to save him." After empathizing with the patient, which of the following is the most appropriate initial response by the physician?
ko: A 35-year-old woman, 15 weeks pregnant, with a severity level of 2, item 1, is taken to the hospital with the onset of labor. The medical team determines that the birth cannot be prevented and that the fetus will not survive. After explaining this to the patient, the patient says, "I know the chances are slim, but I still want to do everything I can to revive the baby and save the baby." en: A 17 -year-old boy is  brought to the clinic for a follow -up examination. He has been evaluated for three episodes of full - body weakness at the ages of 13, 16, and 17 years. en: A 45 -year-old woman comes to the office for a follow -up examination 2 weeks after she sustained a vertebral fracture at  L1. The fracture occurred spontaneously and there is no history of trauma to the area or other fractures. She gained 27  kg (60 lb) during the 6 months before the fracture occurred. Her only medication is hydromorphone as needed for pain.  She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and now weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 38 kg/m2. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse  is 86/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 145/98 mm Hg. Physical examination shows central obesity  and purple striae over the abdomen bilaterally. The lower extremities appear thin. Results of laborat ory studies are  shown:     Plasma      Renin activity  5.0 ng/mL/h (N=0.6 –4.0)   Metanephrine  0.3 nmol/L (N<0.4)   Serum      Cortisol, random  43 μg/dL    Adrenocorticotropic hormone  120 pg/mL (N<120)    Aldosterone  8 ng/dL (N=2 –9)  Urine 24 -hour free cortisol excretion  340 µg/24 h (N=3.5 –45)    The most likely cause of the fracture in this patient is an increase in which of the following processes?
es: A 45-year-old woman presents for a follow-up examination 2 weeks after sustaining a vertebral fracture at L1. en: A 25 -year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 3 -hour history of fever, severe headache, light - headedness, dizziness, shaking chills, and muscle aches. Five hours ago, she was diagnosed with Lyme disease and  began doxycycline therapy. She has no other history of serious illness and takes no other medications. Menses occur at  regular 28 -day intervals. She is currently menstruating and using a tampon. She appears anxious. Temperature is 37.0°C  (98.6°F), pulse is 120/m in, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air  shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. Physical examination shows flushing and diaphoresis. Cardiopulmonary  examination shows no other abnormalities. Which of the follow ing is the most likely mechanism of this patient’s current  condition?

en: A newborn delivered at 36 weeks' gestation to a 22 -year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, has difficulty feeding and  listlessness. The mother received no prenatal care. Spontaneous vaginal delivery was uncomplicated. The mother's only  medication was a prenatal  vitamin. The newborn's length is 49 cm (19 in; 39th percentile), and weight is 3100 g (6 lb  13 oz; 30th percentile); head circumference is 33 cm (13 in; 12th percentile). en: A 60 -year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 4 -day history of fever, joint aches, and rash.  Three weeks ago, she was admitted to the hospital for treatment of Staphylococcal aureus  endocarditis. She has received  21 days out of a prescribed 42 -day course of intravenous oxacillin. Currently, she appears to be in mild distress.  Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mm H g. Pulse  oximetry on room air shows an oxygen sat uration of 97%. Physical examination shows a diffuse maculopapular rash  over the trunk and upper and lower extremities. There is no pus or erythema at the skin insertion site of the peripherally  inserted central catheter line initially placed on the day of  hospital discharge. Results of laboratory studies are shown:     Hemoglobin  11.1 g/dL   Hematocrit  33%  Leukocyte count  12,100/mm3   Segmented neutrophils  78%   Eosinophils  9%   Lymphocytes  7%   Monocytes  6%  Platelet count  341,000/mm3  Serum      Na+ 133 mEq/L    K+ 6.5 mEq/L    Cl− 100 mEq/L    HCO 3− 15 mEq/L    Urea nitrogen  65 mg/dL    Glucose  96 mg/dL    Creatinine  5.7 mg/dL     Urine microscopy shows eosinophils and WBC casts. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this  patient's condition?
es: A 60-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 4-day history of fever, joint pain, and rash. en: A 4-year-old girl with type 1 diabetes mellitus is brought to the emergency department by her father because of a 4 -hour  episode of restlessness, sweating, and confusion that occurred during the night. Yesterday, he allowed her to eat cupcakes  and cotton c andy at a county fair. At her bedtime that evening, he increased her dose of subcutaneous intermediate - acting and long -acting insulin. Her symptoms began 6 hours later, then resolved spontaneously. After being informed  this morning of this nighttime episod e, the mother insisted the father bring the patient to the hospital. On arrival, the  patient is alert. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Her fingerstick blood  glucose concentration is 72 mg/dL. Urinalysis is nega tive for glucose and ketones. Which of the following is the most  likely explanation for this patient's nighttime symptoms?

en: A 15 -year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents to discuss results of a biopsy done 3 days ago for a rapidly  enlarging neck mass. He first noted the mass 1 month ago. Two weeks ago, he was evaluated for an episode of prolonged  epistaxis and was found to have a right ear effusion, which was treated with amoxicillin -clavulanic acid. He has no other  history of serious illness and takes no medica tions. Height is at the 10th percentile, weight is at the 50th percentile, and  BMI is at the 75th percentile. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a right ear effusion and  a 4-cm, firm mass in the right posterior triangle of the  neck. Results of a biopsy specimen show squamous epithelium  with indistinct cell margins, enlarged atypical nuclei, and absent keratin formation. Which of the following infectious  agents is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's current condit ion?

Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a right ear effusion and a 4-cm firm mass in the right posterior triangle of the neck. Results of a biopsy specimen show squamous epithelium with indistinct cell margins, enlarged atypical nuclei, and absence of keratin formation. Which of the following infectious agents is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's current condition?

en: A 48 -year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician for a follow -up examination. Current  medications are metformin and once -daily insulin. She travels frequently and works long hours. She says that her meals  are usually fast food. She leads a sedentary lifestyle. She often forgets to measure her blood glucose concentration. Her  last hemoglobin A 1c was measured as 8.4%. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician to  help this patient improve her diabetic control?
es: A 48-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the physician for a follow-up examination. She is currently taking metformin and insulin once daily. She travels frequently and works long hours. She reports that she tends to eat fast food. She leads a sedentary lifestyle. She often forgets to measure her blood glucose level. Her last hemoglobin A 1c was 8.4%. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician to help this patient improve her diabetes control?

en: A 74 -year-old woman with a history of coronary artery disease is brought to the emergency department 30  minutes after  the sudden onset of crushing chest pain. Her pulse is 120/min, and systolic blood pressure is 70  mm Hg. An ECG shows  sinus rhythm with ST elevation in leads V 1 through V 3. The physician plans to administer a drug to increase the patient's  blood pressure without increasing her pulse. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate for this patient?
es: A 74-year-old woman with a history of coronary artery disease presents to the emergency department 30 minutes after sudden onset of crushing chest pain. Her pulse is 120/min, and her systolic blood pressure is 70 mm Hg. An ECG shows sinus rhythm with ST elevation in leads V1 through V3. The physician plans to give a drug to increase the patient's blood pressure without increasing her pulse. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate for this patient?

en: A 2-month -old girl is  admitted to the hospital because of severe pneumonia. She has a history of mucocutaneous  candidiasis and chronic diarrhea. Her pulse is 160/min, and respirations are 40/min. Crackles are heard over both lung  fields. Her leukocyte count is 5400/mm3 (N=5000 –19,500), with 86% segmented neutrophils, 6% lymphocytes, and 8%  monocytes. Immunologic testing of a specimen obtained via bronchoscopy is positive for Pneumocystis jirovecii . Flow  cytometry shows normal concentrations of natural killer cells but no T or B  lymphocytes in the peripheral blood. Results  of a polymerase chain reaction test of the immunoglobulin V(D)J regions from a bone marrow specimen show an absence  of characteristic rearrangements. The most likely cause of these findings is an alteration of which of the following?
es: A 2-month-old girl is admitted to the hospital with severe pneumonia. She has a history of mucocutaneous candidiasis and chronic diarrhea. The pulse is 160/min and respirations 40/min. Crackles are heard in both lung fields. The white blood cell count is 5400/mm3 (N=5000-19,500), with 86% segmented neutrophils, 6% lymphocytes, and 8% monocytes. Immunologic testing of a specimen obtained by bronchoscopy is positive for Pneumocystis jirovecii . Flow cytometry shows normal levels of natural killer cells but no T or B lymphocytes in the peripheral blood. Results of a polymerase chain reaction assay of the V(D)J regions of immunoglobulin from a bone marrow specimen show an absence of characteristic rearrangements. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these results?

en: A 25 -year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, comes to the office because of a 2 -week history of palpitations and heat  intolerance. She delivered her child 3 months ago following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. She is breast - feeding. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 54 kg  (120 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 106/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure  is 124/68 mm Hg. Examination shows moist pal ms and bilateral lid lag. No exophthalmos is noted. The thyroid gland  is enlarged and nontender. No murmurs are heard on cardiac examination. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+. Serum studies  show an undetectable TSH concentration, thyroxine (T 4) concentration of 20 μg/dL, and triiodothyronine (T 3)  concentration of 275 ng/dL. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of this patient's symptoms?

The thyroid gland is enlarged and nontender. No murmurs are heard on cardiac examination. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+. Serum studies show an undetectable TSH concentration, a thyroxine (T4) concentration of 20 μg/dL, and a triiodothyronine (T3) concentration of 275 ng/dL. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism for this patient's symptoms?

en: A 73 -year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 6 -hour history of severe abdominal pain. Arteriography shows an embolus in the superior  mesenteric artery lodged just beyond the patent middle colic artery. A laparotomy is done . During this procedure, which  of the following segments of the abdominal viscera is most likely to appear normal?

en: A 73 -year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his family 1  hour after he walked into the left side of a  door frame when leaving his bedroom and then tripped over a chair that was on his left side. Visual field testing shows  left lower quadran tanopia. When tactile stimuli are presented on both the left and right sides simultaneously, the patient  correctly identifies only the ones on the right. Further examination shows no motor or language deficits. Proprioception  is intact. This patient most l ikely has a brain lesion in which of the following lobes?
es: A 73-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his family 1 hour after walking into the left side of a door frame while exiting his bedroom and then tripping over a chair that was on his left side. Visual field testing shows left lower quadrant tanopia. When tactile stimuli are presented to him on the left and right sides simultaneously, the patient correctly identifies only those on the right. Subsequent examination shows no motor or language deficits. Proprioception is intact. This patient is likely to have a brain lesion in which of the following lobes?
ar: A 73-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his family 1 hour after he bumped into the left side of a door frame as he exited his bedroom and then tripped over a chair that was on his left side. Visual field testing reveals deficits in the left lower quadrant. When tactile stimuli are presented on both the left and right sides simultaneously, the patient correctly recognizes stimuli on the right side only. Further examination reveals no motor or language deficits. Motor reception is intact. This patient most likely has a brain lesion in which of the following lobes?
cs: A 73-year-old man is brought to the emergency room by his family an hour after he hit the left side of a door frame while leaving his bedroom and then tripped over a chair that was on the left side. Visual field examination shows left lower quadrant tanopia. When tactile stimuli are presented simultaneously on both the left and right sides, the patient correctly identifies only those on the right side. Further examination shows no motor or language deficits. Proprioception is intact. This patient most likely has a brain lesion in which of the following lobes?

Further examination reveals no motor or language deficits. Proprioception is intact. This patient most likely has a brain lesion in which of the following lobes?

ko: A 73-year-old man is brought to the emergency room by his family one hour later after walking out of his bedroom, stepping into a left-hand door frame, and tripping on a chair to the left. Visual field testing reveals left inferior quadrant strabismus. When tactile stimuli are presented simultaneously to the left and right, the patient accurately identifies only those on the right. Further testing reveals no motor or speech deficits. Proprioception is intact. Which of the following is the most likely location of the temporal lobe in which brain lesion does this patient have?
ja: A 73-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his family 1 hour after he bumped into the left side of a door frame while leaving his bedroom and tripped over a chair on the left side.
