en: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the office by her mother because of a 6 -hour history of bloody diarrhea. She is interactive  and in no acute distress. Her blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows normoactive bowel sounds.  Stool cultures ar e obtained, and the patient's mother is advised to give the girl plenty of fluids. Five days later, the patient  develops decreased urine output and is brought back to the office. Her blood pressure is now 135/88 mm Hg. Physical  examination shows pallor. en: A 34 -year-old woman with myasthenia gravis comes to the emergency department because of a 2 -day history of  increasing weakness, shortness of breath, and abdominal cramping. Current medications are prednisone and  pyridostigmine. Her temperature is 37°C (98. 6°F), pulse is 45/min, and respirations are 25/min and shallow. Her voice  is soft and hypernasal, and she coughs weakly when swallowing water. Breath and heart sounds are normal. Pulmonary  testing shows inability to generate a normal negative inspiratory f orce during forced inspiration. The abdomen is soft  and nontender, with increased bowel sounds. Muscle strength is 4/5 diffusely, with severe, continuous, and diffuse  fasciculations. Deep tendon reflexes are sluggish, but symmetric. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this  patient's weakness?
es: A 34-year-old woman with myasthenia gravis presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of increasing weakness, shortness of breath, and abdominal cramps. She is taking prednisone and pyridostigmine. Her temperature is 37°C, her pulse is 45/min, and her respirations are 25/min and shallow. Her voice is soft and hypernasal, and she coughs weakly when swallowing water. Breath and heart sounds are normal. Pulmonary tests show an inability to generate normal negative inspiratory force during forced inspiration. The abdomen is soft and nontender, with increased bowel sounds. Muscle strength is 4/5 diffuse, with severe, continuous, diffuse fasciculations. Deep tendon reflexes are slow but symmetric. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's weakness?
ar: A 34-year-old woman with myasthenia gravis comes to the emergency department with a history of progressive weakness, dyspnea, and abdominal cramps. Current medications are prednisone and pyridostigmine. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 45/min, and respirations are 25/min and shallow. Her voice is soft and hypernasal, and she coughs weakly when swallowing water. Breath and heart sounds are normal. Pulmonary examination shows an inability to generate a normal passive inspiration during forced inspiration. The abdomen is soft and nontender with increased bowel sounds. Muscle strength is diffusely 4/5, with severe, persistent, diffuse cramps. Deep tendon reflexes are slow but symmetrical. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's weakness?
cs: A 34-year-old woman with myasthenia gravis comes to the emergency department because of two days of increasing weakness, shortness of breath, and abdominal cramps. He is currently on prednisone and pyridostigmine. Her temperature is 37°C, pulse 45/min, respirations 25/min and she is shallow. Her voice is soft and hypernasal, and she coughs weakly as she swallows water. Breath and heart sounds are normal. Pulmonary tests show an inability to produce normal negative inspiratory forces during forced inspiration. The abdomen is soft and irrepressible, with increased bowel sounds. Muscle strength is 4/5 diffusely, with severe, continuous and diffuse fasciculations. Deep tendon reflexes are slow but symmetrical. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's weakness?
de: A 34-year-old woman with myasthenia gravis presents to the emergency department complaining of increasing weakness, shortness of breath, and abdominal cramps for 2 days. She is currently taking prednisone and pyridostigmine. She has a temperature of 37°C, a pulse of 45/min, and shallow breathing of 25/min. Her voice is soft and hypernasal, and she coughs weakly when she swallows water. Respiratory and heart sounds are normal. Lung examination shows that she is unable to produce a normal negative inspiratory rate during forced inspiration. The abdomen is soft and intense, with increased bowel sounds. Muscle strength is 4/5 diffuse, with heavy, continuous, and diffuse fasciculations. Deep tendon reflexes are sluggish but symmetrical. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's weakness?
id: A 34-year-old woman with myasthenia gravis presents to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of increasing weakness, shortness of breath, and abdominal cramping. Her current medications are prednisone and pyridostigmine. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), her pulse is 45/min, and her respirations are 25/min and shallow. Her voice is soft and hypernasal, and she coughs weakly with swallowing water. Breath and heart sounds are normal. Pulmonary testing shows an inability to generate a normal negative inspiratory force during forced inspiration. The abdomen is soft but not firm, with increased bowel sounds. Muscle strength is 4/5 diffuse, with severe, continuous, diffuse fasciculations. Deep tendon reflexes are sluggish but symmetrical. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's weakness?
ko: A 34-year-old woman with myasthenia gravis presents to the emergency department with weakness, dyspnea, and abdominal cramps that have been worsening for 2 days. She is currently taking prednisone and pyridostigmine. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), her pulse is 45/min, and her respirations are shallow (25/min). Her voice is soft and nasal, and she coughs weakly when swallowing liquids. Her respiratory and heart sounds are normal. Her pulmonary examination reveals that she is unable to produce normal vocal inspiratory force on forced inspiration. Her abdomen is soft, not tender, and her bowel sounds are increased. Her muscle strength is distributed 4/5, with deep, persistent, and diffuse muscle tone. Her deep tendon reflexes are slow but symmetrical. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's weakness?
ja: A 34-year-old woman with myasthenia gravis visits the emergency department because of a 2-day history of increasing weakness, shortness of breath, and abdominal cramps. Her current medications are prednisone and pyridostigmine. Her temperature is 37°C, her pulse is 45 beats/min, and her respirations are 25 breaths/min, shallow. Her voice is soft and nasal, and she coughs weakly after swallowing water. Breath and heart sounds are normal. Spirometry reveals that she is unable to achieve a normal negative inspiratory pressure during forced inspiration. Her abdomen is soft and nontender, with increased bowel sounds. Strength is diffuse 4/5, with severe, sustained, diffuse muscle contractions. Deep tendon reflexes are sluggish but symmetric. What is the most likely cause of this patient's weakness?
lv: A 34-year-old woman with myasthenia gravis presents to the emergency department because of worsening weakness, shortness of breath, and abdominal cramps two days earlier. Current medications are prednisone and pyridostigmine. Her temperature is 37°C, pulse 45/min, respirations 25/min, and she is shallow. Her voice is low and hypernasal, and she coughs weakly as she swallows water. Breathing and heart sounds are normal. Pulmonary tests show an inability to produce a normal negative respiratory force during forced inspiration. The abdomen is soft and distended, with increased bowel sounds. Muscle strength is 4/5 diffuse, with heavy, continuous and scattered fasciculations. Deep tendon reflexes are slow but symmetrical. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's weakness?

Her voice is soft and hypernasal, and she coughs weakly when swallowing water. Respiratory and cardiac sounds are normal. Pulmonary tests reveal that she is unable to generate a normal negative inspiratory force during forced inspiration. The abdomen is soft and nontender, with increased bowel sounds. Muscle strength is 4/5 diffuse, with severe, continuous, and diffuse fasciculations. Deep tendon reflexes are sluggish but symmetrical. What is the most likely cause of this patient's weakness?

Muscle strength is 4/5 diffusely, with severe, continuous, diffuse fasciculations. Deep tendon reflexes are slow but symmetric. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's weakness?

en: A 35 -year-old woman comes to the office because she has had three first -trimester spontaneous abortions during the past  3 years. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show no endocrine abnormalities.  Chromosomal analysis shows a paracentric inversion of the long arm of chromosome 1. Which of the following best  describes th is patient’s risk for early spontaneous abortions and a liveborn child with aneuploidy?      Risk for Early  Risk for Liveborn    Spontaneous Abortions  Child With Aneuploidy
es: A 35-year-old woman presents with a complaint of three first-trimester miscarriages over the past 3 years. Physical examination reveals no abnormalities. Laboratory studies reveal no endocrine abnormalities. Chromosomal analysis shows a paracentric inversion of the long arm of chromosome 1. Which of the following best describes this situation? Which of the following best describes the patient's risk for early miscarriages and for having a live-born child with aneuploidy? Risk of early miscarriages Risk of a live-born child with aneuploidy
ar: A 35-year-old woman comes to the clinic because she has had three first-trimester spontaneous abortions in the past 3 years. Physical examination reveals no abnormalities. Laboratory studies reveal no endocrine abnormalities. Chromosomal analysis shows an isocentric inversion of the long arm of chromosome 1. Which of the following best describes the patient's risk of early spontaneous abortion and aneuploidy of the liveborn fetus? Risk of early spontaneous abortion, liveborn spontaneous abortion, and aneuploidy
cs: A 35-year-old woman who has had three spontaneous abortions in the last three years in the first trimester comes to the surgery. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory tests show no endocrine abnormalities.  Chromosomal analysis shows a paracentric inversion of the long arm of chromosome 1. Which of the following best describes the risk of early spontaneous abortion and live birth with aneuploidy?      Risk of early spontaneous abortions Risk of a live birth with aneuploidy

en: A 14 -year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother because of a 1 -week history of seizures and difficulty walking.  Physical examination shows decreased sensation over the hands and feet and generalized weakness. He walks with an  ataxic gait. A muscle  biopsy specimen shows coarsely granular fibers that stain red with Gomori trichrome stain. This  patient most likely has a genetic defect that most directly affects the synthesis of which of the following?
es: A 14-year-old boy is brought to your office by his mother because of a 1-week history of seizures and difficulty walking. Physical examination shows decreased sensation in the hands and feet and generalized weakness. He walks in an ataxic manner. A muscle biopsy specimen shows coarse granular fibers that stain red with Gomori trichrome stain. en: A 4-year-old boy develops fever 3 weeks after being admitted to the hospital for induction chemotherapy for treatment  of acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Chemotherapy medications are L-asparaginase, dexamethasone, doxorubicin, and  vincristine. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 122/min, and respirations are 24/min. Physical examination  shows pallor, alopecia, and ulcerations over the gums. A central venous catheter with entry  site in the right upper chest  is present but has no surrounding erythema. A blood culture grows gram -negative rods after 36 hours. Which of the  following underlying mechanisms is the most likely cause of this patient's susceptibility to infection?
es: A 4-year-old boy develops a fever 3 weeks after being admitted to the hospital for induction chemotherapy for acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Chemotherapy drugs include L-asparaginase, dexamethasone, doxorubicin, and vincristine. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.4°F), pulse is 122/min (122/min), and respirations are 24/min (24/min). Physical examination shows pallor, alopecia, and ulcerations over the gingivae. He has a central venous catheter with an entry site in the right upper chest but no surrounding erythema. A blood culture shows gram-negative bacilli after 36 hours. Which of the following underlying mechanisms is most likely the cause of this patient's susceptibility to infection?
